questions.question_text: Look at Fig. 6.1 (a) and identify the parts of a neuron (i) where information is acquired, (ii) through which information travels as an electrical impulse, and (iii) where this impulse must be converted into a chemical signal for onward transmission.
hints: Recall the structure of a neuron: dendrites, axon, axon terminal
Information acquisition happens at sensory receptors or dendrites
Electrical impulses travel along the axon

questions.question_text: Is there a difference in how sugar and food taste if your nose is blocked? If so, why might this be happening? Read and talk about possible explanations for these kinds of differences. Do you come across a similar situation when you have a cold?
hints: Think about the connection between taste and smell
Recall that taste perception involves both gustatory and olfactory senses

questions.question_text: Can you now trace the sequence of events which occur when a bright light is focussed on your eyes?
hints: Start with light detection by photoreceptors
Consider pupil constriction as a protective response

questions.question_text: Study the labelled diagram of the human brain. We have seen that the different parts have specific functions. Can we find out the function of each part?
hints: Identify forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain regions
Recall functions like thinking, balance, involuntary control
Match brain parts to their specific roles in coordination

questions.question_text: Based on what we have discussed so far, what do you think the differences between these would be?
hints: Consider nervous control vs. automatic control
Think about conscious vs. unconscious movement

questions.question_text: What is the difference between a reflex action and walking?
hints: Reflex actions are automatic and rapid
Walking involves conscious control and coordination
Consider brain involvement in both actions

questions.question_text: What happens at the synapse between two neurons?
hints: Signal transmission from one neuron to another

questions.question_text: Which part of the brain maintains posture and equilibrium of the body?
hints: Think about balance and coordination center
Cerebellum is responsible for motor coordination

questions.question_text: How do we detect the smell of an agarbatti (incense stick)?
hints: Olfactory receptors in nose detect chemicals
Signal travels to olfactory bulb in brain

questions.question_text: What is the role of the brain in reflex action?
hints: Most reflexes occur at spinal cord level
Brain may receive information but not always initiate

questions.question_text: Have the old parts of the shoot and root changed direction? Are there differences in the direction of the new growth? What can we conclude from this activity?
hints: Compare old vs new growth patterns

questions.question_text: If 'hydro' means water and 'chemo' refers to chemicals, what would 'hydrotropism' and 'chemotropism' mean? Can we think of examples of these kinds of directional growth movements?
hints: Examples: roots growing toward water, pollen tubes toward ovules

questions.question_text: What are plant hormones?
How is the movement of leaves of the sensitive plant different from the movement of a shoot towards light?
hints: Shoot toward light: slow, growth-based movement
Compare mechanisms: water pressure vs cell elongation

questions.question_text: Give an example of a plant hormone that promotes growth.
How do auxins promote the growth of a tendril around a support?
hints: More growth on side away from support

questions.question_text: Design an experiment to demonstrate hydrotropism.
hints: Set up with water source on one side
Control for other factors like gravity

questions.question_text: Hormones are secreted by endocrine glands and have specific functions. Complete Table 6.1 based on the hormone, the endocrine gland or the functions provided.
hints: Match hormones to their glands: insulin-pancreas, testosterone-testes
Recall functions: adrenaline-fight or flight, thyroxin-metabolism
Use textbook information to fill missing entries

questions.question_text: How does chemical coordination take place in animals?
Why is the use of iodised salt advisable?
How does our body respond when adrenaline is secreted into the blood?
hints: Prepares for fight or flight response

questions.question_text: Why are some patients of diabetes treated by giving injections of insulin?
hints: Diabetes involves insulin deficiency or resistance

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a plant hormone? (a) Insulin (b) Thyroxin (c) Oestrogen (d) Cytokinin.
hints: Cytokinin: plant hormone promoting cell division

questions.question_text: The gap between two neurons is called a (a) dendrite. (b) synapse. (c) axon. (d) impulse.
The brain is responsible for (a) thinking. (b) regulating the heart beat. (c) balancing the body. (d) all of the above.
What is the function of receptors in our body? Think of situations where receptors do not work properly. What problems are likely to arise?
hints: Examples: taste buds, photoreceptors, touch receptors

questions.question_text: Draw the structure of a neuron and explain its function.
hints: Label dendrites, cell body, axon, myelin sheath, axon terminal
Explain signal reception, transmission, and release of neurotransmitters
Connect structure to function in nervous coordination

questions.question_text: How does phototropism occur in plants?
Which signals will get disrupted in case of a spinal cord injury?
How does chemical coordination occur in plants?
hints: Diffusion or transport to target cells

questions.question_text: What is the need for a system of control and coordination in an organism?
How are involuntary actions and reflex actions different from each other?
hints: Involuntary: controlled by brain (e.g., heartbeat, breathing)
Reflex: rapid, automatic, often spinal cord mediated
Both are automatic but differ in control center and speed

questions.question_text: Compare and contrast nervous and hormonal mechanisms for control and coordination in animals.
hints: Nervous: fast, electrical impulses, specific pathways
Hormonal: slow, chemical messengers, widespread effects
Both work together for integrated control

questions.question_text: What is the difference between the manner in which movement takes place in a sensitive plant and the movement in our legs?
hints: Sensitive plant: rapid, non-growth, turgor pressure change
Human leg: voluntary, muscle contraction, nervous control
Different mechanisms: plant cells vs animal muscle tissue
